titleStmt.title: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T Static Output Feedback Control of Nonhomogeneous Markovian Jump Systems with Asynchronous Time Delays

analytic.title: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T Static Output Feedback Control of Nonhomogeneous Markovian Jump Systems with Asynchronous Time Delays

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper investigates the problem of static output feedback control for a class of nonhomogeneous Markovian jump system (NMJS) with asynchronous time delays (ATDs). Since the ATDs subject to uncertain transition probabilities (TPs) are taking into account in a practical phenomenon, new approaches are introduced to deal with the ATDs characterized by nonhomogeneous Markov processes. It is assumed that the communication links are not perfect due to its detrimental effect on the performance of systems. Stochastic variables are presented to characterize the data transmission, which are depending on operation modes and satisfying the Bernoulli distribution. Sets of slack variables are adopted to decouple the product terms between system matrices and Lyapunov matrices. Based on an extended Lyapunov function combined with Finsler inequality approach, the robust static output-feedback controller is designed for the closed-loop NMJS. Finally, a numerical example is provided to verify the design method.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Over the past few decades, Markovian jump systems (MJSs) have been attracting considerable attention for its strong practical application with random, such as networked control systems, economics systems, communication systems, see [1][2][3][4][5][40][41][42] and the references therein. It has been shown that, the random

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: jumps and abrupt changes amongst different modes are usually determined by a finite state Markov process.

It is well known that, in switching process, the behaviors of systems are governed by the transition probabilities (TPs) [6]. In the major existing literature, the TPs are always remaining constant with the lapse of time, which is called homogeneous MJSs, and extensive research results have been achieved in the field of stability [7][8][9][10]39], and control design [11][12][13][14][15][16][43][44][45].

Most of the aforementioned researches assume that the Markov chain is time-invariant, however, in the problem of practical engineering, the assumption that the TPs keep time-invariant is not realistic. For example, the random component failures (RCFs) always exist in systems, so it is impossible to assume that the RCFs are both state-independent and time-independent due to the disturbance of solicitation degree and other factors. Other examples can be referred to manufacturing systems and the voltage convert circuit system. It is reasonable to consider a dynamic system with nonhomogeneous Markov chain, that is NMJSs. So far, the issues of NMJSs have been widely addressed in [17][18][19][20][21], which use the potentials of NMJSs and thus can be less intrinsic conservative. However, among these references, the TPs are assumed to be known prior, which is impossible in practice. Generally speaking, it is costly and time consumingly to get the probability known exactly in the switching processes. In fact, the stability analysis of continuous-time MJSs with uncertain transition probabilities (UTPs) has been involved in [26][27], which makes MJSs with UTPs more practical in applications. For example, Kao et al. [26] addressed the problem of continuous time singular MJSs with UTPs, where the UTPs were characterized by partly unknown estimate value. To mention a few, the existing results are mainly about continuous-time MJSs [25][26]. However, so far, there
has not yet any attention focused on discrete-time NMJSs with UTPs, especially the case of NMJSs with ATDs by nature. It is challenging and significant to investigate NMJSs with both ATDs and UTPs.

In parallel, there has been an increasing attention devoted to static output-feedback (SOF) control. It is easy to be implemented with low cost and the aid of SOF controller. In practise, it is well known that the dynamic output-feedback controller can be formulated by the structure of SOF controller, under this circumstances, the issue of SOF control has been attracted considerable attentions [29][30][31][32][33][46][47][48]. However, the above-mentioned results are mainly focus on the linear systems. Nevertheless, the problem of SOF

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T control for MJSs has not been investigated yet, not mention to SOF control for NMJSs, which motivates us to this study.

Motivated by the aforementioned discussion, in this paper, we deal with the issue of static output feedback control for a class of NMJS with ATDs, in order to develop computationally effective results. The main contributions of this paper are fourfold.

1) The asynchronous Markov time delays are proposed, as a f irst attempt, in the field of NMJSs. In the control perspective, it is more appropriate to consider the NMJSs with ATDs than the conventional ones.

2) Owing to the bounded uncertainty description, the TPs are modeled as additive uncertain transition specifications, where the uncertainty is generally time-varying and presented by its upper and lower bounds.

3) It is assumed that, there exists the intermittently data-packet dropout in communication links, and stochastic variables are characterized as operation modes dependent and satisfies the Bernoulli distribution, which renders the current study more practical significance. 4) Sets of slack variables are presented in decoupling between Lyapunov and systems matrices, and SOF control gains are designed in achieving a robust H ∞ -disturbance index.

The rest of the paper is briefly summarized as follows. Section II is devoted to the formulation of problem. The main results for SOF control of Nonhomogeneous Markovian Jump Systems with ATDs are presented in Section III. A numerical example is devoted in Section IV to verify the design methodology and conclusion is given in Section V.

div.head: Notations:
div.p: The notations throughout the paper are fairly standard. R n represents the n dimensional Euclidean space, and R m×n denotes the set of all m × n real matrices, * stands the elements below the main diagonal of a symmetric block matrix. • means the Euclidean vector norm. The norm z(k
div.formula: ) E2 = E[ ∞ k=0 | z(k) | 2 ]. He(Q) represents the abbreviate Q + Q T . diag{. . .} denotes the block diagonal matrix.
div.p: In (Ω, F, P), Ω means the sample space, F refers to subsets of sample space and P stands the probability measure on F. E{•} stands for the mathematical expectation.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Asynchronous Markov Random Delays
div.p: From the engineering perspective, y(k) refers the NMJS measurement output which can be measured by sensors and may contain sensor delays:
div.formula: y(k) = E(r k , σ k )x(k) + E w (r k , σ k )x(k -d θ k (k))(6)
div.p: where E(r k , σ k ) and E w (r k , σ k ) denote the output matrices with compatible dimensions. The modedependent ATDs are assumed to be randomly determined by a Markov chain {θ k , k ≥ 0} and satisfies
div.formula: d 0 < d θ k (k) < d M , where d 0 = min θ k ∈N1 {d θ k (k)}, d M = max θ k ∈N1 {d θ k (k)} and d = d M -d 0 . The ATDs A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T d θ k (k)
Pr(θ k+1 = n | θ k = m, σ k = p) = λ (p) mn(7)
div.p: where
div.formula: λ (p)
div.p: mn > 0, ∀m, n ∈ N 2 , ∀p ∈ K denotes the TP from mode m at time k to mode n at time k + 1, and
div.formula: N2 j=1 λ (p) mn = 1 for all m, n ∈ N 2 . In (7), λ(p)
div.p: mn is also modeled as a function of the high-level switching signal
div.formula: σ k = p.
div.p: Similarly, the TPs matrix Λ (p) can be expressed as
The mode TPs λ In this paper, we consider the following mode-dependent switching control law for NMJS (1):
div.formula: u c (k) = K r k ,θ k ,σ k y c (k) (10
div.p: where y c (k) ∈ R ny and u c (k) ∈ R nu indicate the input and output of the controller, respectively. K r k ,θ k ,σ k ∈ R nx×ny labeled the gain matrices of the controller.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Communication Links
div.p: There always exist the data losses and communication links from the physical plant to the controller, i.e., the random dropouts occur between the measurements of plant and input of the controller, that is
div.formula: y(k) = y c (k).
div.p: Similarly, the controller is not equivalent to the actuator, that is u(k) = u c (k). Therefore, a class of NMJS subject to unreliable communication links is depicted in Fig. 2. The physical plant in Fig. 2 is revealed by Nonhomogeneous Markovian jump model, both uplink and downlink contain the unreliable communications. In current study, a stochastic variable technique is presented to model the phenomenon of data losses:
div.formula: y c (k) = α r k (k)y(k), u(k) = β r k (k)u c (k)(11)
div.p: where {α r k (k)} and {β r k (k)} are the independent stochastic variables in the Bernoulli processes. Specifically, α r k (k) and β r k (k) take the values of 0 and 1, where α r k (k) = 0 and β r k (k) = 0 represent the failed transmission, α r k (k) = 1 and β r k (k) = 1 show the successful transmission. Then, one has
div.formula: Prob{α r k (k) = 1} = E {α r k (k)} = α r k , Prob{α r k (k) = 0} = 1 -α r k , Prob{β r k (k) = 1} = E {β r k (k)} = β r k , Prob{β r k (k) = 0} = 1 -β r k .(12)
div.p: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T

In the following analysis, we denote e r k (k), where e r k (k) = α r k (k)β r k (k). It can be concluded that e r k (k) = 1 if and only if α r k (k) = 1 and β r k (k) = 1. Otherwise, it yields that e r k (k) = 0. Based on (12),
div.formula: one has Prob{e r k (k) = 1} = E {e r k (k)} = e r k , Prob{e r k (k) = 0} = 1 -e r k .(13)
div.p: It follows from (11) that
div.formula: u(k) = e r k (k)K i,m,p y(k).(14)
div.p: Denoting
div.formula: e r k (k) = e r k (k) -e r k ,(15)
div.p: it follows from ( 13) and (15) that
div.formula: Prob{ e r k (k)} = 0, Prob{ e r k (k) e r k (k)} = (1 -e r k )e r k .(16)

div.head: Closed-Loop System
div.p: From (1), ( 6) and ( 10)-( 16), the closed-loop NMJS is given by
div.formula:        x(k + 1) = (A i,m,p + e(k)D i,m,p )x(k) + (B 0 i,m,p + e(t)D w i,m,p )x(k -d θ k (k)) + B w i,p ω(k), z(k) = C i,p x(k) + D w i,p ω(k),(17)
div.p: where
div.formula: D i,m,p = B i,p K i,m,p E i,p , A i,m,p = A i,p + e i D i,m,p , D w i,m,p = B i,p K i,m,p E w i,p , and B 0 i,m,p = e i D w i,m,p .
div.p: Before presenting the main objective of current study, we introduce the following definitions.

div.head: Definition 2.1([28])
div.p: The closed-loop NMJS ( 17) is said to be stochastically stable if, when ω(k) = 0 for
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T any initial condition x 0 ∈ R n , r 0 ∈ N 1 , θ 0 ∈ N 2 and σ 0 ∈ M, the following inequality holds: E    ∞ f =0 x(f ) 2 | (r 0 , θ 0 , σ 0 )    < ∞. (18
div.p: Robust H ∞ Static-Output Feedback-Control Problem: Let us consider the NMJS subject to unreliable communication links depicted in Fig. 1, suppose the unreliable communication link parameter ēr k is given prior, for a given scalar γ > 0, a SOF controller is designed in the form of (10), such that:
(1) Stochastic stability: The closed-loop NMJS in ( 17) is stochastically stable in the sense of Definition 2.1;
(2) H ∞ performance: Under zero-initial conditions, the controlled output z(k) satisfies
div.formula: z(k) E ≤ γ ω(k)
div.p: where z(k 1) and ( 2) are satisfied, then the closed-loop NMJS in ( 17) is called stochastically stable with a guaranteed H ∞ performance γ.
div.formula: ) E = E { ∞ k=0 | z(k) | 2 }. If both conditions (

div.head: Definition 2.2 ([19]
div.p: ) For a deterministic switching signal σ k and any k > k 0 , let N σ (k 0 , k) be the jumping number of σ k over an interval (k 0 , k). If for the given N 0 > 0 and τ a > 0, one has
div.formula: N σ (k 0 , k) ≤ N 0 +(k-k 0 )/τ a ,
div.p: τ a and N 0 are respectively said to be average dwell time and chatter bound. As commonly used in the published references, we assume N 0 = 0.
Lemma 2.1 (Finsler's Lemma [33]): Let ξ(k) ∈ R n , P = P T ∈ R n×n , and H ∈ R m×n such that rank(H ) = r < n, the following statements are equivalent:
div.formula: (1) ξ T (k)Pξ(k) < 0, for all ξ(k) = 0, H ξ(k) = 0; (2) ∃Q ∈ R n×m : P + QH + H T Q T < 0.

2 N i,p + N1 j=1 N2 n=1 1 4 (ε (p) ij (p) mn ) 2 U j,n,p .
div.p: the closed-loop NMJS ( 17) is stochastically stable and has a guaranteed performance index γ.
Proof. See Appendix A.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T
div.formula: N 2 N 2 + ε (p) N 2 N 2 ]                   . A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T Remark 4.
div.p: Inspired by the mode-dependent parameter approach in [35], the scalars α r k , β r k and e r k are dependent on the NMJS mode r k in ( 11) and ( 14), with the aid of mode-dependent parameter method, less conservative conditions can be achieved in this paper. It is noted that we only require Bernoulli processes associated with the r k -th subsystem.

Remark 5. It is noted that, in the aforementioned derivation, two mutually independent stochastic processes are proposed for stochastic stability of the NMJS with asynchronous time delays. In [34], two continuoustime homogeneous stochastic chains are introduced to model the time delays. Different from [34], the novel stochastic processes are first proposed in current study, which characterized by two mutually independent discrete-time nonhomogeneous Markov processes.

Remark 6. The novel Lyapunov function in (22) is more general, which can be widely used in many practical application. This is because the information of stochastic chain, asynchronous Markov time delays and switching signal are applied.

Remark 7. In the most existing literature, the Finsler's Lemma 2.1 is employed to get rid of variables in linear matrix inequalities. In this paper, with the aid of Finsler's Lemma 2.1, the equivalence between ( 43) and ( 44) is achieved and the decoupling effect between matrices P i,m,p and matrices A i,m,p involves slack matrix variables are obtained.
Remark 8. It should be pointed out that, to obtain less conservative criteria, sets of slack variables are introduced in decoupling between Lyapunov and systems matrices.

Remark 9. Note that the TPs play an important role in the system behavior, and it is very difficult to acquire the precise value of TPs for the NMJS. In this paper, the more general UTPs are introduced
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: in the closed-loop NMJS (17). In practice, the values for the UTPs can be obtained through measurement method.
Now, we are in a position to present the sufficient conditions for the existence of a static output controller for the NMJSs with ATDs in the following theorem.
Theorem 3.2 Consider system (17) with ATDs and let γ > 0, κ > 1,

div.p: Combing ( 30)- (32), it yields that ( 19) and ( 26) are equivalent. Hence, the conclusion of Theorem 2.2 follows immediately from Theorem 2.1, which completes the proof.

Remark 8. It is worth mentioning that, the matrix B i,p plays an important role in choosing the term T i,p . It is easy to obtain T i,p since the matrix B i,p is given. Usually, T i,p in ( 5) is not unique and can be given by
div.formula: T i,p =     (B T i,p B i,p ) -1 B T i,p (B T ⊥ i,p ) T     .(33)

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Numerical example and simulation
div.p: As depicted in Fig. 3, consider a modified Pulse-Width-Modulation (PWM) driven boost converter [36], [37]:
with
div.formula: τ = t T , L = L T , C rτ = C rτ T , C rt =                  C 1 , if r t = 1 C 2 , if r t = 2 C 3 , if r t = 3
div.p: where s(t) is the switch device which can switch only one time in period T and controlled by PWM, R denotes the load resistance, C rt represent the capacitances, L stands for the inductance, and u s (t) means the source voltage. As shown in Fig. 3, the transformation of source voltage is represented by converter in circuit system. It is noted that, the s(t) denotes switching signal, which switches from one terminal point to another, and leads to vary voltages of load circuit. It can be seen in Fig. 3, three positions are occupied

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: by switch s(t), which can be modeled as Markov process with three modes.
Letting
The equation ( 63) can be represented as NMJS:
div.formula: ẋ(τ ) = A(r τ , σ τ )x(τ ) + B(r τ , σ τ )u(τ ).
div.p: Setting sampling time T s = T 10 , the obtained continuous-time NMJS (63) can be descretized and the UTP matrices are given by
The system matrices are given as follows:
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T 1.
div.p: C 1 operates and s(t) contacts point 1
2. C 1 operates and s(t) contacts point 2
3. C 2 operates and s(t) contacts point 1
4. C 2 operates and s(t) contacts point 2
5. C 3 operates and s(t) contacts point 1
Furthermore, the random Markov chain θ k is described as

The state response of the open-loop NMJs is shown in Fig. 4. From the figure, it is clear that the open-loop NMJS is not stable. The object of current study is to design the static output feedback controller such that the closed-loop NMJS with ATD and unreliable communication link is stochastically stable with a guaranteed performance index γ.

It is noted that, with the aid of inequalities (55)-(57), the minimal static feedback performance index γ min is governed by the unreliable communication links. As listed in Table 1, different γ min can be achieved with various (e 1 , e 2 , e 3 ), the index γ min becomes larger as the mode-dependent parameter e i (i = 1, 2,

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: To illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy, fix the sequences of Bernoulli processes e 1 = 0.6, e 2 = 0.8 and e 3 = 0.9, set = 0.8, ν = 1.5 and d 0 = 1, by solving the LMIs in Theorem 3.2, it yields that

It is clear that one can obtain the minimal dwell time τ * a = 12.8212. For given time step 0 to 20, the switching signal is depicted in Fig. 5 under the condition of ADT. It is noted that, the Markov chain r k is governed by system mode and Markov chain θ k is determined by asynchronous random time delay. The values of r k and θ k are respectively shown in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7 under different TP matrices. For the given initial condition x(0) = [-0.2 0.2] T , the disturbance input is described by ω(k) = e -0.5k sin(0.25k).

The trajectory of the closed-loop NMJS is depicted in Fig. 8, It is clear that state response is converging to zero point in the stochastically sense with the proposed feedback control approach, which implies the stability of the closed-loop NMJS (17).

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: This paper makes the first attempt to deal with the static output feedback control for a class of NMJS solvable and have great advantages from a practical point of view. Compared with the existing references about MJSs, the system in this paper is more complex due to the existence of ATDs. It is noted that, one future work is to extend the obtained results to event-triggered and sliding-mode control for NMJS subject to ATDs due to its widely applications in the practical systems.

figure.head: Remark 3 .
figure.figDesc: Normally, it is impossible to obtain the exact elements of the time-varying TPs (TVTPs) π (p) ij and λ (p) mn . Owing to the bounded uncertainty description, the focus has moved to TVTPs modeled by a class of uncertain transition specifications, where the upper and lower bounds of TVTPs are available:

are characterized by a discrete-time nonhomogeneous Markov chain, which take values in the finite set N 2 = {1, 2, • • • , N 2 }, and subject to the uncertain TP matrix λ (p) :

Remark 1. It is worth to emphasize that, the current random time delays in the real communication systems are always correlated with the previous NMJSs modeled by stochastic process r k . It is reasonable to introduce the asynchronous Markov time delays d θ k (k), where Markov chain θ k is nonhomogeneous and takes value in N 1 if TPs λ mn are time variant. It should be noted that the time delays modeled in[21,31] are homogeneous Markov chains. While the asynchronous Markov time delays d θ k (k) in this paper are modeled as a nonhomogeneous Markov chain, which has some advantage over that of[21,31].

note.p: Remark 2. The mode-dependent controller K r k ,θ k ,σ k are firstly attempted to be designed for NMJSs(1), which contain Markov chain r k , asynchronous Markov time delays d θ k (k) and switching signal σ k , therefore, the static output-feedback controller(10) involves more information of NMJS(1). The proposed new technique may be seen as a novel way to tackle with NMJS subject to ATDs.
